True can have nothing to the meaning. For instance window can be 'half-open', not 'open' or 'shut' - it can be true. Consider the list of simple antonyms.

column8: This is an epistemic-level conditional, different from the conditional in (8). In German, it is hardly possible to say 'Wenn es nicht regnen soll, werden wir gehen'. The sentence in (9) is possible only if the apodosis is an inference ('dann schneit es bei mir bestimmt auch', i.e. then I infer that it rains here too).

I would say that 30b would still not evaluate to false.   In 29a, there is one reading with specific reference, and one with non-specific reference. in 30, both readings are specific. as indicated by the definite article.   What do the following sentences tell us?  (1) John is looking for the owner of the dog that bit him, but not for Al Capone  vs.  (2) John hates the owner of the dog that bit him, but he loves Al Capone.   (2) is definitely fine, but for (1), I am less sure. I am not convinced that (1) is weird either.   In any case, I just wanted to mentioned that I found this example not obvious, and maybe it could be replaced by another one without harm for the argument.
